I believe this must be a recent regression in CDT CVS HEAD. 

The only other thing that changed was that I upgraded to arm-elf-gdb 6.3.

I've got the oportunity to debug this more tomorrow, if I get some instructions/hints as to what I should be looking for.

Looks strange. The last stack depth is 2 and at the same time the number of old frames is 4.
Do you have a simple test case?

(In reply to comment #3)
> Looks strange. The last stack depth is 2 and at the same time the number of old
> frames is 4.
> Do you have a simple test case?

No.

This is at a clients, so I'll only have access to this problem occasionally.

If you can give me some instructions for debugging and what to look for, 
I can perhaps put together a more effective bug-report.

(In reply to comment #4)
> This is at a clients, so I'll only have access to this problem occasionally.
> If you can give me some instructions for debugging and what to look for, 
> I can perhaps put together a more effective bug-report.

The gdb trace could be useful.
I can add a check to prevent this exception, but I would like to find what causes it first.
Thanks.

1. I started a debug session.
2. Clicked "Suspend"

Oyvind,

As far as I can figure out this is the problem:

[1,133,959,257,745] &"info threads\n"
[1,133,959,257,755] &"warning: RMT ERROR : failed to get remote thread list\n"
[1,133,959,257,755] &"\n"
[1,133,959,257,755] &"warning: Couldn't restore frame in current thread, at frame 0\n"

Because the thread list is not available the debugger assumes that there is only one thread. But in fact there is more than one thread.
Here is a possible scenario.
You do a step in a thread that has three frames and when the debugger is stepping you press the "suspend" button.
The program stops in the different thread which has only one frame. But the debugger thinks that it is in the same thread and this causes an error.
Does it sound plausible?

(In reply to comment #8)
> Oyvind,
> 
> As far as I can figure out this is the problem:
> 
> [1,133,959,257,745] &"info threads\n"
> [1,133,959,257,755] &"warning: RMT ERROR : failed to get remote thread list\n"
> [1,133,959,257,755] &"\n"
> [1,133,959,257,755] &"warning: Couldn't restore frame in current thread, at
> frame 0\n"
> 
> Because the thread list is not available the debugger assumes that there is
> only one thread. 

This is with a JTAG debugger, so there is no threads concept.

>But in fact there is more than one thread.

No. The JTAG debugger acts as if there is only one thread.

> Here is a possible scenario.
> You do a step in a thread that has three frames and when the debugger is
> stepping you press the "suspend" button.

A frequent operation, yes.

> The program stops in the different thread which has only one frame. But the
> debugger thinks that it is in the same thread and this causes an error.
> Does it sound plausible?

No.

With a JTAG debugger there are no threads as such(even if the underlying 
operating system being debugged has multiple threads, GDB aren't aware of these threads).

However, I can see how the assumption that threads exist and a JTAG debugger, 
where GDB sees only a single "thread", can cause confusion.

This is what causes the problem.
The program is suspended with the following stack:

116^done,stack=[frame={level="0",addr="0x01034db0",func="RIMIChannel::commitGain\
Table",file="board/RIMIChannel.cc",line="188"},frame={level="1",addr="0x0109cfe0",func="$a",file="f1\
/F1.cc",line="990"},frame={level="2",addr="0x0109cfe0",func="$a",file="f1/F1.cc",line="990"}]

You do "-exec-next 1" and then "suspend" and the program ends up in the completely different stack:

121^done,stack=[frame={level="0",addr="0x00000018",func="~basic_stringstream",fi\
le="sstream",line="606"}]

The only explanation is this is a different thread.

Ok, I'll see what I can do with it.

(In reply to comment #10)
> This is what causes the problem.
> The program is suspended with the following stack:
> 
> 116^done,stack=[frame={level="0",addr="0x01034db0",func="RIMIChannel::commitGain\
> Table",file="board/RIMIChannel.cc",line="188"},frame={level="1",addr="0x0109cfe0",func="$a",file="f1\
